context: Ending A: The Legend Never Dies — High overall relationships, Legend path. Time-lapse of Driver's legacy across years.

lines.text: Years pass. The way years do — in flashes.
A mural on the side of Maya's garage. Fresh paint, bright colors. Your car, mid-drift, trailing light like a comet.
A kid stops to stare at it on the way to school. Every morning. Same kid. Same hungry eyes.
The Downtown strip renamed. Not officially — the city council would never. But everyone who matters calls it by your name.
Race nights dedicated to you. Trophies with your silhouette. Stories told in garages at 2 AM by people who weren't even born when you ran Route 9.
The stories get bigger every year. The times get faster. The margins get wider. That's how legends work — they grow in the telling.
Five years out. Ten. Twenty.
Nova Pacifica changes. Buildings go up. Buildings come down. The harbor road gets widened. Route 9 stays the same — it's protected now. Historical landmark. Someone fought for that.
Maya fought for that.
The garage is still there. Bigger now. A school, really. Young mechanics learning the way Maya learned — hands-on, oil under fingernails, no shortcuts.
Nikko runs a team. Legitimate. Sponsors, liveries, the whole deal. He never stops telling people he beat you once. Nobody believes him. He doesn't care.
And Diesel...

lines.label: diesel_alive
lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: People ask me about those days. The early days.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: They want the races. The times. The cars. They want to know if the stories are true.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: I tell them the stories don't do it justice. They never do.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: They came from nothing. They lost everything. And then they built something that can never be taken away.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: A legend.

lines.label: diesel_gone
lines.text: Diesel's coupe sits in a glass case at the harbor overlook. Untouched. The plaque just says his name and two dates. Nothing else needed.
People leave flowers on the hood sometimes. And photos of their builds. He would have hated that. He would have secretly loved it.
Dawn. The harbor district. A statue unveiled last year — not a statue of you, exactly. A figure leaning against a car, looking at the horizon. Could be anyone. But everyone knows.
A kid stops in front of it. Beat-up sneakers. Hands in pockets. Eyes that have seen more than they should at that age.
Behind the kid, parked crooked against the curb, a car. Old. Dented. Held together by will and wire and something the kid can't name yet.
The kid looks at the statue. Looks at the car. Looks back at the statue.
Same hungry eyes.
Same beat-up car.
Same city that takes everything and gives nothing back — unless you take it.
The kid gets in the car. The engine coughs, catches, holds. A sound like a promise.
The cycle begins again.
THE LEGEND NEVER DIES
